Comment: 1SG has separate subject (S/A) and object (P) forms, while all other person and number combinations are neutrally aligned.

Feature: Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?

Comment: NP recipients must take a preposition. However, pronominal arguments do not take any flagging.

Comment: “Although reduplication may have been been used to form new words in the early pidgin, it is no longer used as a grammatical process in [Torres Strait Creole], except in the secret language used by children.”

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?
Comment: “Although reduplication may have been been used to form new words in the early pidgin, it is no longer used as a grammatical process in [Torres Strait Creole], except in the secret language used by children.”

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: “Although reduplication may have been been used to form new words in the early pidgin, it is no longer used as a grammatical process in [Torres Strait Creole], except in the secret language used by children.”

Comment: “Em ‘them’ is never used of living creatures. As an object personal pronouns, it refers to plural inanimate objects which cannot breathe or move of their own accord. Here em ‘them’ and the verb which it follows are spelled as one word.”

Comment: Words such as ebribodi ‘everybody’ and ebriting ‘everything’ were recent borrowings into Torres Strait Creole at the time of writing and beginning to supplant the “older form” olgeda ‘all’.

Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Comment: “Each simplex sentence in [Torres Strait Creole] is made up of two distinct parts: an optional subject and an obligatory predicate.” However, the only sentences which have no overt subject are impersonal sentences and existential sentences.
